How do you rate the new city administration on storm clean-up? I give them an F. We live in the heart of the city and the silence (i.e. lack of plowing) is DEAFENING! We all moved our cars. With the first storm (aka the blizzard) they didn't plow and then they lifted the parking ban, when we had no place to put our automobiles. Our new mayor is either totally incompetent or totally arrogant and disregards the heart of the city. I particularly liked his smug dig at Secretary of State Kerry for not clearing his sidewalk. Well guess what, Mayor Walsh? The sidewalks - the purview of the residents and businesses - are pretty good. The city streets - the city's responsibility, your mess!

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Noted. Thank you for contacting the Boston Transportation Department regarding your concerns with the operation and safety concerns of the the intersection and traffic signal at Columbus Avenue and Dartmouth Street. We are aware of the tragic accident that occurred between a school bus and a pedestrian and his dog. I want to assure you we are looking at remedies to improve the operation at this intersection. It is quite challenging due to the traffic volumes, two-way streets on both Dartmouth St and Columbus Avenue, limited geometry to allow widening for turn lanes, and pedestrian volumes as well. We are in the process of retiming the Back Bay traffic signals and this intersection is part of the study. Our goal is to come up with a signal phasing that will improve pedestrian safety and accommodate vehicles as well, without causing more backups in your neighborhood. Currently, the traffic signal has concurrent walks for pedestrians (Walks in the same direction of traffic) and it also has turning arrows from Dartmouth SB to Columbus inbound as well as a right turn arrow from Columbus outbound to Dartmouth northbound.  One issue we have observed is pedestrians crossing Columbus Ave on the east side during the turning arrow phases even though the pedestrian signals display Don't Walk.  They see the traffic signal on Columbus Ave turn red and assume they can walk across, especially from south to north where they cannot see the turning arrows. The benefit of an exclusive only pedestrian phase (all-walk, all-red for cars) is it is the absolute safest condition for pedestrians.  The downside to an exclusive is it adds delays to the overall intersection causing longer vehicular queues, longer cycle lengths (the amount of time for a signal to serve all approaches before starting over), and even longer pedestrian delays because a pedestrian will have to wait for other phases to happen before finally receiving the exclusive all-walk.  This can lead to pedestrians becoming impatient and jaywalking, putting themselves in harms way. Our current plan is to add an exclusive pedestrian phase.  Our study shows the north crosswalk across Dartmouth St is best to only operate under this condition due to the amount of left and right turning vehicles from Columbus Avenue to Dartmouth St NB.  This crosswalk will only turn on during the exclusive pedestrian phase and will display Don't Walk at all other times.  All other crosswalks will also be on during the exclusive pedestrian phase but will remain on during the concurrent traffic phases as well.  We will also eliminate the turn arrows on Dartmouth SB and Columbus outbound to Dartmouth NB, since our analysis shows arrows are not warranted and have a limited effect without a dedicated left-turn lane on to store traffic and there is no room to add one. A hybrid exclusive/concurrent pedestrian operation should improve pedestrian safety but also not increase pedestrian delay too much overall. I hope I explained our understanding of the situation and our plan that we hope to enact in Spring 2015 (some of the improvements require restriping and we must wait until after the winter).  Before then we will be making some adjustments to yellow/red times and pedestrian times to the way the signal currently operates.

status_notes: Case Closed. Duplicate of Existing Case. case closed see 1243385.
description:
At the location of 692A Washington Street in Chinatown, each week, there is an alarm which goes off all evening long. The fire department has been unresponsive to this issue so far.

With all the new residential developments in the area, the constant ringing of the alarm through the night keeps residents awake. Please note that the alarm rings for about 5 minutes, turns off for 60 seconds and then turns back on. So if it is not ringing at the moment you arrive, simply wait a moment. It is occurring as I type this message, on the evening of January 6th at 10:00 PM. There is no telling if someone is to come out on the 7th or the next day of it will be ringing but it has been occurring at least once per week as of late. Please advise as to how we can best resolve this, thank you!

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. As stated in the original CRM the ADA requires that all crosswalks need a pedestrian ramp on either side. If you are in a wheel chair how can you access a crosswalk where there is curb stone?  In this particular location there was one ramp on one side and edge stone on the other side. In addition the crosswalk was right where the buses pulled up in front of the school. Basically is appears that the crosswalk was installed without meeting specifications for the convenience of people trying to get access to the school. That is why the engineer could not replace that particular crosswalk. Hopefully this explains the situation. If you would like to further discuss this you can contact me at the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. The Boston Public Works Department Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) has identified the sidewalk left in asphalt as belonging to National Grid. In addition we determined that the adjacent cracking was the result of the National Grid work, and they will be responsible to restore. Since there is a moratorium on concrete work until April 1st, the patch will have to stay as is.  The CIU inspector will inspect periodically to make sure that the HMA holds up during the winter. National Grid has been notified that they must restore the sidewalk to concrete in the Spring of 2015. The location has been entered into the CIU data base that tracks repairs to be made by utility companies or private contractors. The CIU will monitor the progress of the repair. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. What you see on the roadway is a type of pavement preservation called 'crack seal'. The purpose of this is to give the roadway a few more years of life before it needs to be resurfaced. The random patterns are simply where the cracks have been covered. This will prevent salt, sand, etc. from seeping into the cracks and heaving the road. It's applied on a 'per neighborhood' basis which may explain why you see it on some adjacent streets and not others. Thank you for your question!

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. Good afternoon,. What you see around the manhole is called 'crackseal'. It's a type of proactive pavement preservation the Public Works Department implements in order to give the roadway a few more years of life before it needs to be resurfaced. Once the winter is over, and the temps warm up, it will set into road more and result in a smoother drive. It's put down on a per neighborhood basis, which may explain why you may not see everywhere. If you have any further questions, don't hesitate to email myself (Matthew.Albanese@boston.gov) or John Vozzella (John.Vozzella@boston.gov). Enjoy your weekend!

Good Evening Mr. Bunker,. *I received a notification from the Mayor's hotline that you were asking. why bus transportation for after school sports is being cancelled.  I. apologize, but that is all the information that I have received.  I would. like to discuss with you and be able to fully investigate the question. Would you mind providing a phone number to reach you at? I would like to. discuss.  Also please feel free to call me. My contact information is. below.   The office line of 617-635-6055 is direct to me.*. *Sincerely,*. *Jonathan*. When he gives me a contact number or responds via email I will find out. what school and sport he is speaking to and also if this was a one time. event or if he is inquiring about permanent cancellation.   I am assuming. that he is speaking to a particular day, but some coaches have been using. the MBTA to get to practices etc. so I wanted to make sure we understood. the issue before responding. Thanks,. Jonathan.
